nodes.text: A likelihood-based vector autoregressive (VAR) framework can model cointegration among nonstationary time series and provide valid inference on cointegration rank, cointegrating vectors, adjustment parameters, and related hypotheses

Three parametric formulations represent cointegration: regression residual approach (Engle-Granger), autoregressive error-correction VAR formulation Delta x_t = alpha beta' x_{t-1} + ... , and unobserved components formulation

The I(1) VAR model with deterministic terms is specified as Delta x_t = alpha(beta' x_{t-1} + Upsilon D_t) + sum Gamma_i Delta x_{t-i} + Phi d_t + epsilon_t and under conditions produces stationary Delta x_t and stationary cointegrating relations beta' x_t

Granger Representation Theorem: under unit roots and the I(1) condition rank(alpha_perp Gamma beta_perp) not zero, the VAR solution decomposes into r stationary cointegrating relations beta' x_t and p-r common stochastic trends, with a moving average representation x_t = cumulative shocks + stationary part + deterministic part

I(1) condition: characteristic polynomial roots either outside unit circle or equal one, and the nondegeneracy condition |alpha_perp Gamma beta_perp| != 0 is required to ensure solutions are I(1) and avoid I(2) or higher

Interpretation of cointegrating coefficients: a cointegrating vector beta relates to long-run equilibrium relations; coefficients can be interpreted as long-run effects (counterfactual keeping other long-run values fixed) via the projector C linking current shocks to long-run adjustments

Likelihood-based inference: Gaussian maximum likelihood estimators for VAR cointegration parameters are obtained via reduced rank regression (RRR) on residuals from conditioning lags and deterministic terms

Reduced rank regression algorithm: solve eigenvalue problem of residual covariance matrices to obtain beta and alpha estimates and maximized likelihood |Omega_hat| = |S00| product_{i=1}^r(1-lambda_hat_i), yielding the likelihood ratio statistic -2 log LR = -T sum_{i=r+1}^p log(1-lambda_hat_i) for testing cointegration rank

Asymptotic distribution of the rank test depends on deterministic terms and number of common trends p-r: the limit is a functional of Brownian motion (Dickey-Fuller family) and tables must account for trend/deterministic specification

Asymptotic distribution of estimators: the estimator of beta (cointegrating vectors), scaled by T, is mixed Gaussian (conditional Gaussian given common trends) while alpha and short-run parameters are asymptotically Gaussian and asymptotically independent of beta; likelihood ratio and Wald tests on beta are asymptotically chi-square

Practical specification checks are crucial: choose lag length; test residuals for normality, autocorrelation, heteroscedasticity; model outliers, structural breaks, parameter instability because violations (especially autocorrelation or parameter changes) invalidate asymptotic results

Weak exogeneity and conditional inference: if some rows of alpha are zero the corresponding variables are weakly exogenous and full maximum likelihood inference on remaining cointegration parameters can be done via the conditional model

Extensions and alternative models: the VAR cointegration framework extends to rational expectations restrictions, I(2) dynamics with associated parametrizations and new asymptotic distributions, seasonal or explosive roots, fractional integration, and nonlinear cointegration models

Limitations and open problems: small sample distortions require corrections or bootstrap; nonlinear cointegration theory is underdeveloped; economic theory must better integrate empirical findings on nonstationary data

Conclusion: the likelihood-based cointegrated VAR provides a coherent toolkit for empirical macro and financial time series analysis, but requires careful specification testing, appropriate asymptotic/small-sample adjustments, and further theoretical and applied development
